slides.content:
# Introduction to Programming Fundamentals

Welcome to **Programming** - teaching computers to solve problems!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Variables and Types** - Storing data
- **Control Flow** - Making decisions
- **Functions** - Reusable code
- **OOP** - Object-oriented concepts

> **Fun Fact:** The first programmer was Ada Lovelace in the 1840s!

slides.title: Variables and Data Types
slides.content:
# Variables and Data Types

## Variables:
- Named storage for data
- Can change value

## Common Data Types:

| Type | Description | Example |
|------|-------------|--------|
| Integer | Whole numbers | 42, -7 |
| Float | Decimals | 3.14, -0.001 |
| Boolean | True/False | true, false |
| Character | Single letter | 'A', '9' |
| String | Text | "Hello" |

## Type Systems:
- **Static:** Types checked at compile time
- **Dynamic:** Types checked at runtime
- **Strong:** No implicit conversions
- **Weak:** Allows conversions

## Declaration:
```
int age = 25;
String name = "Alice";
bool isStudent = true;
```

slides.title: Functions
slides.content:
# Functions

## Definition:
Reusable block of code that performs a task.

## Anatomy:
```
returnType functionName(parameters) {
    // body
    return value;
}
```

## Example:
```
int add(int a, int b) {
    return a + b;
}

int result = add(3, 5);  // result = 8
```

## Concepts:

| Term | Meaning |
|------|--------|
| Parameter | Variable in definition |
| Argument | Value passed when calling |
| Return | Output value |
| void | No return value |

## Scope:
- Local: Inside function only
- Global: Accessible everywhere

## Recursion:
- Function calls itself
- Needs base case to stop

slides.content:
# Programming Summary

## Data Types:
- int, float, bool, char, String

## Control Flow:
- if/else, switch
- for, while, do-while

## Functions:
- Reusable code blocks
- Parameters and return values
- Recursion

## OOP Pillars:
| Pillar | Key Concept |
|--------|------------|
| Encapsulation | Hide data |
| Inheritance | Extend classes |
| Polymorphism | Override methods |
| Abstraction | Hide complexity |

## Best Practices:
- Clean code, DRY, testing

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Programming Fundamentals!
